Title: Why does this way of solving inequalities work?
Content: Here is what I had to prove. Question: For positive reals $a$ and $b$ prove that $a^2+b^2 \geq 2ab$. Here is how my teacher did it: First assume that it is in fact, true that $a^2+b^2 \geq 2ab$. Therefore $a^2+b^2-2ab \geq 0$ . We have $(a-b)^2$ is greater than or equal to zero which is true. Hence what was assumed originally is true. Why does this method work? I cannot understand how you can first assume that it is true and then prove that it is.
AcceptedAnswer:
As written your teacher's proof is incorrect. The correct way to write your teacher's proof would be to write  $$a^2+b^2 \geq 2ab\iff a^2+b^2-2ab \geq 0\iff(a-b)^2\geq 0$$
where each of the statements are equivalent to each other.  The final statement is true, hence so is the first. It is much cleaner to write the proof in the reverse direction i.e. $$(a-b)^2\geq 0\implies a^2+b^2-2ab \geq 0\implies a^2+b^2 \geq 2ab$$
